inlineContent.text: Generics are one of the most powerful features of Swift, and much of the Swift standard library is built with generic code. In fact, you’ve been using generics throughout the
, even if you didn’t realize it. For example, Swift’s
types are both generic collections. You can create an array that holds
values, or an array that holds

values, or indeed an array for any other type that can be created in Swift. Similarly, you can create a dictionary to store values of any specified type, and there are no limitations on what that type can be.
Here’s a standard, nongeneric function called

code: func swapTwoInts(_ a: inout Int, _ b: inout Int) {

inlineContent.text: This function makes use of in-out parameters to swap the values of
function swaps the original value of
. You can call this function to swap the values in two

code: print("someInt is now \(someInt), and anotherInt is now \(anotherInt)")
// Prints "someInt is now 107, and anotherInt is now 3"

func swapTwoDoubles(_ a: inout Double, _ b: inout Double) {

It’s more useful, and considerably more flexible, to write a single function that swaps two values of

In all three functions, the types of
aren’t of the same type, it isn’t possible to swap their values. Swift is a type-safe language, and doesn’t allow (for example) a variable of type
to swap values with each other. Attempting to do so results in a compile-time error.
can work with any type. Here’s a generic version of the

. Type parameters specify and name a placeholder type, and are written immediately after the function’s name, between a pair of matching angle brackets (such as
Once you specify a type parameter, you can use it to define the type of a function’s parameters (such as the
function), or as the function’s return type, or as a type annotation within the body of the function. In each case, the type parameter is replaced with an
type whenever the function is called. (In the
the first time the function was called, and was replaced with
the second time it was called.)
You can provide more than one type parameter by writing multiple type parameter names within the angle brackets, separated by commas.
In most cases, type parameters have descriptive names, such as

, which tells the reader about the relationship between the type parameter and the generic type or function it’s used in. However, when there isn’t a meaningful relationship between them, it’s traditional to name them using single letters such as
Always give type parameters upper camel case names (such as
) to indicate that they’re a placeholder for a
In addition to generic functions, Swift enables you to define your own
. These are custom classes, structures, and enumerations that can work with
type, in a similar way to
This section shows you how to write a generic collection type called
. A stack is an ordered set of values, similar to an array, but with a more restricted set of operations than Swift’s
type. An array allows new items to be inserted and removed at any location in the array. A stack, however, allows new items to be appended only to the end of the collection (known as
a new value on to the stack). Similarly, a stack allows items to be removed only from the end of the collection (known as
The concept of a stack is used by the
class to model the view controllers in its navigation hierarchy. You call the
method to add (or push) a view controller on to the navigation stack, and its
method to remove (or pop) a view controller from the navigation stack. A stack is a useful collection model whenever you need a strict “last in, first out” approach to managing a collection.
The illustration below shows the push and pop behavior for a stack:
There are currently three values on the stack.
A fourth value is pushed onto the top of the stack.
The stack now holds four values, with the most recent one at the top.
The top item in the stack is popped.
After popping a value, the stack once again holds three values.

When you extend a generic type, you don’t provide a type parameter list as part of the extension’s definition. Instead, the type parameter list from the
type definition is available within the body of the extension, and the original type parameter names are used to refer to the type parameters from the original definition.
The following example extends the generic
type to add a read-only computed property called
, which returns the top item on the stack without popping it from the stack:

Note that this extension doesn’t define a type parameter list. Instead, the

computed property can now be used with any
instance to access and query its top item without removing it.

code: print("The top item on the stack is \(topItem).")
// Prints "The top item on the stack is tres."

inlineContent.text: Extensions of a generic type can also include requirements that instances of the extended type must satisfy in order to gain the new functionality, as discussed in
type can work with any type. However, it’s sometimes useful to enforce certain

on the types that can be used with generic functions and generic types. Type constraints specify that a type parameter must inherit from a specific class, or conform to a particular protocol or protocol composition.
type places a limitation on the types that can be used as keys for a dictionary. As described in
, the type of a dictionary’s keys must be
. That is, it must provide a way to make itself uniquely representable.
needs its keys to be hashable so that it can check whether it already contains a value for a particular key. Without this requirement,
couldn’t tell whether it should insert or replace a value for a particular key, nor would it be able to find a value for a given key that’s already in the dictionary.
This requirement is enforced by a type constraint on the key type for
, which specifies that the key type must conform to the
protocol, a special protocol defined in the Swift standard library. All of Swift’s basic types (such as
) are hashable by default. For information about making your own custom types conform to the
You can define your own type constraints when creating custom generic types, and these constraints provide much of the power of generic programming. Abstract concepts like
characterize types in terms of their conceptual characteristics, rather than their concrete type.

You write type constraints by placing a single class or protocol constraint after a type parameter’s name, separated by a colon, as part of the type parameter list. The basic syntax for type constraints on a generic function is shown below (although the syntax is the same for generic types):

code: func someFunction<T: SomeClass, U: SomeProtocol>(someT: T, someU: U) {

Here’s how you might expect a generic version of

code: func findIndex<T>(of valueToFind: T, in array:[T]) -> Int? {

inlineContent.text: This function doesn’t compile as written above. The problem lies with the equality check, “
”. Not every type in Swift can be compared with the equal to operator (

). If you create your own class or structure to represent a complex data model, for example, then the meaning of “equal to” for that class or structure isn’t something that Swift can guess for you. Because of this, it isn’t possible to guarantee that this code will work for
, and an appropriate error is reported when you try to compile the code.
All is not lost, however. The Swift standard library defines a protocol called
, which requires any conforming type to implement the equal to operator (
) and the not equal to operator (
) to compare any two values of that type. All of Swift’s standard types automatically support the
can be used safely with the
function, because it’s guaranteed to support the equal to operator. To express this fact, you write a type constraint of
as part of the type parameter’s definition when you define the function:

code: func findIndex<T: Equatable>(of valueToFind: T, in array:[T]) -> Int? {

inlineContent.text: function now compiles successfully and can be used with any type that’s

code: // doubleIndex is an optional Int with no value, because 9.3 isn't in the array
// stringIndex is an optional Int containing a value of 2

inlineContent.text: When defining a protocol, it’s sometimes useful to declare one or more associated types as part of the protocol’s definition. An

gives a placeholder name to a type that’s used as part of the protocol. The actual type to use for that associated type isn’t specified until the protocol is adopted. Associated types are specified with the
Here’s an example of a protocol called
, which declares an associated type called
protocol defines three required capabilities that any container must provide:
It must be possible to add a new item to the container with an
It must be possible to access a count of the items in the container through a
It must be possible to retrieve each item in the container with a subscript that takes an

This protocol doesn’t specify how the items in the container should be stored or what type they’re allowed to be. The protocol only specifies the three bits of functionality that any type must provide in order to be considered a
. A conforming type can provide additional functionality, as long as it satisfies these three requirements.
Any type that conforms to the

protocol must be able to specify the type of values it stores. Specifically, it must ensure that only items of the right type are added to the container, and it must be clear about the type of the items returned by its subscript.
protocol needs a way to refer to the type of the elements that a container will hold, without knowing what that type is for a specific container. The
protocol needs to specify that any value passed to the
method must have the same type as the container’s element type, and that the value returned by the container’s subscript will be of the same type as the container’s element type.
protocol declares an associated type called
is—that information is left for any conforming type to provide. Nonetheless, the
alias provides a way to refer to the type of the items in a
, and to define a type for use with the
method and subscript, to ensure that the expected behavior of any

above, adapted to conform to the

It can also be useful to define requirements for associated types. You do this by defining a
clause enables you to require that an associated type must conform to a certain protocol, or that certain type parameters and associated types must be the same. A generic
keyword, followed by constraints for associated types or equality relationships between types and associated types. You write a generic
clause right before the opening curly brace of a type or function’s body.
The example below defines a generic function called

instances contain the same items in the same order. The function returns a Boolean value of
if all items match and a value of

The two containers to be checked don’t have to be the same type of container (although they can be), but they do have to hold the same type of items. This requirement is expressed through a combination of type constraints and a generic

code: // Check that both containers contain the same number of items.
// Check each pair of items to see if they're equivalent.
// All items match, so return true.

are type parameters for two container types to be determined when the function is called.

must be the same as the

The third and fourth requirements combine to mean that the items in
operator, because they’re exactly the same type as the items in
function to compare the two containers, even if they’re of a different container type.
function starts by checking that both containers contain the same number of items. If they contain a different number of items, there’s no way that they can match, and the function returns
After making this check, the function iterates over all of the items in

). For each item, the function checks whether the item from
isn’t equal to the corresponding item in

If the loop finishes without finding a mismatch, the two containers match, and the function returns
values, and pushes three strings onto the stack. The example also creates an
instance initialized with an array literal containing the same three strings as the stack. Even though the stack and the array are of a different type, they both conform to the
protocol, and both contain the same type of values. You can therefore call the
function with these two containers as its arguments. In the example above, the
function correctly reports that all of the items in the two containers match.

content.text: Extensions with a Generic Where Clause

inlineContent.text: You can also use a generic
clause as part of an extension. The example below extends the generic
structure from the previous examples to add an
method first checks that the stack isn’t empty, and then compares the given item against the stack’s topmost item. If you tried to do this without a generic
clause, you would have a problem: The implementation of
doesn’t require its items to be equatable, so using the
operator results in a compile-time error. Using a generic
clause lets you add a new requirement to the extension, so that the extension adds the
method only when the items in the stack are equatable.
If you try to call the
method on a stack whose elements aren’t equatable, you’ll get a compile-time error.
clause with extensions to a protocol. The example below extends the
protocol from the previous examples to add a
method first makes sure that the container has at least one item, and then it checks whether the first item in the container matches the given item. This new
method can be used with any type that conforms to the
protocol, including the stacks and arrays used above, as long as the container’s items are equatable.
clause in the example above requires
to conform to a protocol, but you can also write a generic
to be a specific type. For example:
. It iterates over the items in the container to add them up, and divides by the container’s count to compute the average. It explicitly converts the count from
to be able to do floating-point division.
You can include multiple requirements in a generic
clause that’s part of an extension, just like you can for a generic
clause that you write elsewhere. Separate each requirement in the list with a comma.
clause as part of a declaration that doesn’t have its own generic type constraints, when you’re already working in the context of generic types. For example, you can write a generic
clause on a subscript of a generic type or on a method in an extension to a generic type. The
clauses in the example below specify what type constraints have to be satisfied to make these new methods available on a container.

In the version of this example that uses contextual
are both in the same extension because each method’s generic

content.text: Associated Types with a Generic Where Clause

inlineContent.text: clause on an associated type. For example, suppose you want to make a version of
that includes an iterator, like what the
protocol uses in the standard library. Here’s how you write that:

code: associatedtype Iterator: IteratorProtocol where Iterator.Element == Item

inlineContent.text: requires that the iterator must traverse over elements of the same item type as the container’s items, regardless of the iterator’s type. The
function provides access to a container’s iterator.
For a protocol that inherits from another protocol, you add a constraint to an inherited associated type by including the generic
clause in the protocol declaration. For example, the following code declares a

code: protocol ComparableContainer: Container where Item: Comparable { }

clauses. You write the placeholder type name inside angle brackets after

protocol adds a subscript that takes a sequence of indices and returns an array containing the items at each given index. This generic subscript is constrained as follows:
in angle brackets has to be a type that conforms to the
The subscript takes a single parameter,

clause requires that the iterator for the sequence must traverse over elements of type
. This ensures that the indices in the sequence are the same type as the indices used for a container.
Taken together, these constraints mean that the value passed for the
parameter is a sequence of integers.

abstract.text: enables you to write flexible, reusable functions and types that can work with any type, subject to requirements that you define. You can write code that avoids duplication and expresses its intent in a clear, abstracted manner.

A function or method with an opaque return type hides its return value’s type information. Instead of providing a concrete type as the function’s return type, the return value is described in terms of the protocols it supports. Hiding type information is useful at boundaries between a module and code that calls into the module, because the underlying type of the return value can remain private. Unlike returning a value whose type is a protocol type, opaque types preserve type identity—the compiler has access to the type information, but clients of the module don’t.
A
defines a blueprint of methods, properties, and other requirements that suit a particular task or piece of functionality. The protocol can then be
by a class, structure, or enumeration to provide an actual implementation of those requirements. Any type that satisfies the requirements of a protocol is said to
to that protocol.
and

are general-purpose, flexible constructs that become the building blocks of your program’s code. You define properties and methods to add functionality to your structures and classes using the same syntax you use to define constants, variables, and functions.
An
defines a common type for a group of related values and enables you to work with those values in a type-safe way within your code.
A
is called immediately before a class instance is deallocated. You write deinitializers with the
keyword, similar to how initializers are written with the
keyword. Deinitializers are only available on class types.
add new functionality to an existing class, structure, enumeration, or protocol type. This includes the ability to extend types for which you don’t have access to the original source code (known as
). Extensions are similar to categories in Objective-C. (Unlike Objective-C categories, Swift extensions don’t have names.)

Enumerations are often created to support a specific class or structure’s functionality. Similarly, it can be convenient to define utility classes and structures purely for use within the context of a more complex type. To accomplish this, Swift enables you to define
, whereby you nest supporting enumerations, classes, and structures within the definition of the type they support.
Swift provides a variety of control flow statements. These include
loops to perform a task multiple times;
, and
statements to execute different branches of code based on certain conditions; and statements such as
and
to transfer the flow of execution to another point in your code.
Classes, structures, and enumerations can define

, which are shortcuts for accessing the member elements of a collection, list, or sequence. You use subscripts to set and retrieve values by index without needing separate methods for setting and retrieval. For example, you access elements in an
instance as
and elements in a
instance as

is the process of preparing an instance of a class, structure, or enumeration for use. This process involves setting an initial value for each stored property on that instance and performing any other setup or initialization that’s required before the new instance is ready for use.
are self-contained chunks of code that perform a specific task. You give a function a name that identifies what it does, and this name is used to “call” the function to perform its task when needed.

doc://com.apple.Swift/documentation/Swif.title: Declaring Protocol Adoption with an Extension

abstract.text: is a process for querying and calling properties, methods, and subscripts on an optional that might currently be
. If the optional contains a value, the property, method, or subscript call succeeds; if the optional is
, the property, method, or subscript call returns
. Multiple queries can be chained together, and the entire chain fails gracefully if any link in the chain is

doc://com.apple.Swift/documentation/Swif.title: Associated Types with a Generic Where Clause

abstract.text: An
is a special symbol or phrase that you use to check, change, or combine values. For example, the addition operator (
) adds two numbers, as in
, and the logical AND operator (
) combines two Boolean values, as in
A class can
methods, properties, and other characteristics from another class. When one class inherits from another, the inheriting class is known as a
, and the class it inherits from is known as its
. Inheritance is a fundamental behavior that differentiates classes from other types in Swift.
Swift provides three primary

, known as arrays, sets, and dictionaries, for storing collections of values. Arrays are ordered collections of values. Sets are unordered collections of unique values. Dictionaries are unordered collections of key-value associations.
Swift is a new programming language for iOS, macOS, watchOS, and tvOS app development. Nonetheless, many parts of Swift will be familiar from your experience of developing in C and Objective-C.

associate values with a particular class, structure, or enumeration. Stored properties store constant and variable values as part of an instance, whereas computed properties calculate (rather than store) a value. Computed properties are provided by classes, structures, and enumerations. Stored properties are provided only by classes and structures.
In addition to the operators described in
, Swift provides several advanced operators that perform more complex value manipulation. These include all of the bitwise and bit shifting operators you will be familiar with from C and Objective-C.

restricts access to parts of your code from code in other source files and modules. This feature enables you to hide the implementation details of your code, and to specify a preferred interface through which that code can be accessed and used.
Swift uses

(ARC) to track and manage your app’s memory usage. In most cases, this means that memory management “just works” in Swift, and you don’t need to think about memory management yourself. ARC automatically frees up the memory used by class instances when those instances are no longer needed.

doc://com.apple.Swift/documentation/Swif.title: Adding Protocol Conformance with an Extension

abstract.text: By default, Swift prevents unsafe behavior from happening in your code. For example, Swift ensures that variables are initialized before they’re used, memory isn’t accessed after it’s been deallocated, and array indices are checked for out-of-bounds errors.
Swift has built-in support for writing asynchronous and parallel code in a structured way.

can be suspended and resumed later, although only one piece of the program executes at a time. Suspending and resuming code in your program lets it continue to make progress on short-term operations like updating its UI while continuing to work on long-running operations like fetching data over the network or parsing files.

means multiple pieces of code run simultaneously—for example, a computer with a four-core processor can run four pieces of code at the same time, with each core carrying out one of the tasks. A program that uses parallel and asynchronous code carries out multiple operations at a time; it suspends operations that are waiting for an external system, and makes it easier to write this code in a memory-safe way.

doc://com.apple.Swift/documentation/Swif.title: Extensions with a Generic Where Clause

abstract.text: is a way to check the type of an instance, or to treat that instance as a different superclass or subclass from somewhere else in its own class hierarchy.

are functions that are associated with a particular type. Classes, structures, and enumerations can all define instance methods, which encapsulate specific tasks and functionality for working with an instance of a given type. Classes, structures, and enumerations can also define type methods, which are associated with the type itself. Type methods are similar to class methods in Objective-C.
are self-contained blocks of functionality that can be passed around and used in your code. Closures in Swift are similar to blocks in C and Objective-C and to lambdas in other programming languages.

is the process of responding to and recovering from error conditions in your program. Swift provides first-class support for throwing, catching, propagating, and manipulating recoverable errors at runtime.
A
is a series of characters, such as
or
. Swift strings are represented by the
type. The contents of a
can be accessed in various ways, including as a collection of
values.
